title: Fix unreported WASM runtime error
body:
### Description

This PR fixes unreported Runtime errors. There are three levels of errors from `handle_events`: elapsed, join error, or (WASM) runtime error. Currently, on `develop`, the runtime error is not reported.

### Testing steps

Set `start_block: 8322` in `fuel-explorer` and run:

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --manifest examples/fuel-explorer/fuel-explorer/fuel_explorer.manifest.yaml --replace-indexer
```

On `develop`, there is no error. On this branch, `fuel-explorer` fails.

See #1090 for additional information.

### Changelog

* Report WASM runtime errors from WasmIndexExecutor

title: Fix start_block behavior when resumable flag is set.
body:
### Description

This PR fixes start_block behavior when the `resumable` is set #1080. Currently, `start_block` is only respected if `resumable` is not set in the manifest.

### Testing steps

In `fuel_explorer.manifest.yaml`, set:
```
start_block: 8300
resumable: true
```

Then:

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --manifest examples/fuel-explorer/fuel-explorer/fuel_explorer.manifest.yaml --replace-indexer
```

And the indexer starts at block 8300. Next, `C-c`, and:

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80
```

And the indexer starts at the last block it stopped at (`last block > 8300`).

Then:

```
start_block: 8300
resumable: false
```

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --manifest examples/fuel-explorer/fuel-explorer/fuel_explorer.manifest.yaml --replace-indexer
```

And again, the indexer starts at `8300`. Next, `C-c`, and:

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80
```

And the indexer starts at `8300`.

### Changelog

* Fix `resumable` behavior.

### Testing steps

Please provide the _exact_ testing steps for the reviewer(s) if this PR requires testing.

This PR also changes how `load_schema` works and how it is called. It is now a private function called from `Database::new`. Previously it would fetch the namespace and identifier from the manifest for the native executor and through FFI from the WASM executor. The latter is unnecessary. title: use tokio::runtime::Handle::current() in get_object and put_object
body:
### Description

Since `get_object` and `put_object` are called inside the context of a `tokio` runtime, we can reuse it with `tokio::runtime::Handle::current()`

  - Still need to persist the data into the m2m table and allow for a way to query though
- Integrates last remaining types from #897 
  - The v1 block explorer is essentially finished!! 🥳 🥳 

### Some (really rough) stats
- Stats are just from a snapshot of my computer
- A 2022 M2 chip with 24GB RAM, 8 CPUs
```bash
> uname -a
Darwin [..] Darwin Kernel Version 22.1.0: [ ... ]/RELEASE_ARM64_T8112 arm64
```

- 32 blocks/second
- ~100% CPU
- 30+ threads
  - Why so many threads for a single executor? 
    - Are they sqlx threads?
- Data size (at Block#125060)
  - 874 MB / 125060 (blocks) = ~7KB per block
```bash
postgres=# SELECT schema_name,
       pg_size_pretty(sum(table_size)::bigint),
       (sum(table_size) / pg_database_size(current_database())) * 100
FROM (
  SELECT pg_catalog.pg_namespace.nspname as schema_name,
         pg_relation_size(pg_catalog.pg_class.oid) as table_size
  FROM   pg_catalog.pg_class
     JOIN pg_catalog.pg_namespace ON relnamespace = pg_catalog.pg_namespace.oid
) t
GROUP BY schema_name
ORDER BY schema_name;
    schema_name     | pg_size_pretty |          ?column?
--------------------+----------------+----------------------------
 fuel_explorer      | 874 MB         |    85.09221162849698165300
 information_schema | 88 kB          | 0.008364440305203270644300
 pg_catalog         | 7712 kB        |     0.73302913220145026400
 pg_toast           | 144 MB         |    13.97089652068179014100
 public             | 432 kB         |     0.04106179786190696500
(5 rows)
```

title: forc index kill: terminate or kill
body:
### Description

This PR changes the default behavior of `forc index kill` to send the `TERM` signal and adds a `-9` flag to send the `KILL` signal instead. This way, the behavior matches the Linux `kill` command.

The motivation for this is that `fuel-indexer` may be running with `--embedded-database`, in which case the current behavior of `forc index kill` won't allow `fuel-indexer` to shut down the embedded `postgres` process—it will be left alive.

If the user attempts to start `fuel-indexer` again with `--embedded` database, they will get an error.

title: fix: downgrade `fuel-core-client` to `v0.17.2`
body:
### Description

This PR downgrades `fuel-core-client` to `v0.17.2` as the move to the latest version negatively impacted our ability to index information from the beta-3 testnet. It also downgrades a few other dependencies as well; special care has been taken to minimize the amount of downgrading necessary.

When either beta-3 is upgraded or a new testnet is released, we should be able to revert this PR to get rid of the manual type conversions and make only a few necessary adjustments to move to the required version.

### Testing steps

CI should pass.

#### Manual Testing

Please compile the `fuel-explorer` example and run the following command: 
```
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --manifest examples/fuel-explorer/fuel-explorer/fuel_explorer.manifest.yaml --run-migrations --verbose --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80
```

You should see that beta-3 is being successfully indexed once more.

### Notes

For the testing suite, I had to downgrade `fuels-rs` to `v0.40` (our previously used version); this was because of difficulties with the built-in `fuel-core` helpers (for starting the test node) and working with the downgraded types.

title: enhancement: implement instantiation methods for entity types
body:
Closes #951 and #963.

### Description
This PR adds a `::new()` method to entity types that automatically calculates an ID for the user so that they do not have to come up with their own way to create one. It also adds a `::get_or_create()` method that will load a record from the DB if present or create the struct as described above.

### Testing steps

The `hello-world` example has been changed to illustrate the new instantiation methods.
1. Ensure the test DB is cleared and that the `hello-world` WASM module has been freshly built.
2. `cargo run -p hello-world-node`
3. `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --manifest examples/hello-world/hello-indexer/hello_indexer.manifest.yaml --verbose`
4. `cargo run -p hello-world-data`
5. Check the output of the indexer; you should see that the original and `::new()` methods insert data into the DB, and that `::get_or_create()` loads a record from the database.

### Changelog

- Add a number of `HashSet`s for checking whether a field type implements the requisite traits
- Add a helper function for creating the necessary method implementations

title: enhancement: implement union types

labels.name: fuel-explorer
labels.description: This PR is directly related to the block explorer

body:
- [ ] Please add proper labels
- [ ] If there is an issue associated with this PR, please link the issue (right-hand sidebar)
- [ ] If there is not an issue associated with this PR, add this PR to the "Fuel Indexer" project (right-hand sidebar)

### Description

- This PR adds support for `union` types in GraphQL
- `union` types are created using a the set of fields between all the union's members
- Some notes:
  - Tables _will_ be created from union types (even if the contents of the union are themselves unindexable)
- `union` types work very similarly to `object` types
  - The main difference is, when using an `object`, the fields are directly on the object
  - However, when using a `union`, you have to look up the members of the union in order to find the set of fields shared between all members of the union
- `union` fields are _all_ optional, except the `ID` field.
- Tests were added
- I will integrate this new functionality into the explorer after this PR is merged
- [More detail on why this approach](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/issues/988#issuecomment-1584518964)

### Testing steps

- [ ] Tests were added so CI should pass
- [ ] Run the service on beta-3 with the test indexer and inspect your tables

```bash
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --manifest  packages/fuel-indexer-tests/components/indices/fuel-indexer-test/fuel_indexer_test.yaml --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --verbos
```

### Description

- Whilst deploying an indexer to the playground I noticed authentication was buggy
- This PR fixes 3 issues:
  - Removes auth from `register_indexer_assets`
  - Fixes sqlx type issue in `queries::indexer_owned_by`
  - Uses the public key in `index_registry` (not the issuer)
- This was previously unnoticed cause I never run the indexer locally with auth (will change that going forward)
- Obviously an integration test would help here. Happy for anyone to open that PR ;) 

### Testing steps

- [ ] You will need two accounts in your `forc-wallet` (account index `0` and account index `1`)
- [ ] Start the service with auth enabled on beta3
```bash
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --auth-enabled --auth-strategy jwt --jwt-secret abcdefg --jwt-issuer FuelLabs
```
- [ ] Authenticate using your first account `forc index auth`
- [ ] Use this token to deploy an indexer `forc index deploy --auth $TOKEN1`
  - On master this fails due to the SQLx type issue _and_ the unnecessary authentication check
- [ ] Authenticate using your second account `forc index auth`
- [ ] Use this token to try to remove the indexer your just deployed `forc index remove --auth $TOKEN2`
  - This will fail as `Unauthorized`
 

### Changelog

- fix: various auth updates

title: fix: update `forc index`'s `--native` indexer creation and usage
body:
- [ ] Please add proper labels
- [ ] If there is an issue associated with this PR, please link the issue (right-hand sidebar)
- [ ] If there is not an issue associated with this PR, add this PR to the "Fuel Indexer" project (right-hand sidebar)

### Description

- Whilst initially looking into https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/issues/966 wanted to use `chrono` to keep track of block indexing time, but can't use it in WASM execution cause of https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/issues/408, so decided to use native. 
- Noticed that some aspects of native don't work via the plugin
- Just now noticing this cause no one (rightfully so, at this time) uses native execution

### Testing steps

- [ ] Build `forc-index` locally `cargo build -p forc-index --release`
  - Use this ☝🏽 forc-index when testing
- [ ] Create a native indexer `forc-index new indexer-test --namespace fuel --native && cd indexer-test`
- [ ] Build it `forc-index build --native`
- [ ] Run it `cargo run -- --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --run-migrations --manifest indexer_test.manifest.yaml`
  - Yes running via `cargo` is not ideal and not the final state

title: fuel-indexer run --replace-indexer
body:
- [ ] Please add proper labels
- [ ] If there is an issue associated with this PR, please link the issue (right-hand sidebar)
- [ ] If there is not an issue associated with this PR, add this PR to the "Fuel Indexer" project (right-hand sidebar)

### Description

Add `--replace-indexer` flag which changes how `forc index deploy` works: deployed indexer completely replaces the existing indexer(s) under the same UID. All previous indexer assets, graphql entries, and indexer tables are removed.

### Testing steps

I have a simple contract/script/indexer which may be helpful: https://github.com/lostman/fuel-counter

1. Run `cargo run --features fuel-core-lib -p fuel-indexer -- run --local-fuel-node --replace-indexer`
2. `git clone https://github.com/lostman/fuel-counter`
3. Create an indexer with colliding UID `examples.counter_indexer` that we will replace later:
```
mkdir dummy && cd dummy && forc index new --namespace examples counter_indexer && cd counter_indexer && forc deploy
```
4 Deploy the `counter` contract, an indexer, and run a script to trigger an event: `cd fuel-counter && make`
5. Confirm that the dummy indexer was replaced and that an event was indexed:
```
postgres=> select * from examples_counter_indexer.increntity;
         id          | value |                                 object
---------------------+-------+------------------------------------------------------------------------
 7003491485461406310 |   123 | \x02000000000000000d0000000166626662666631611e000000017b00000000000000
 ```

### Changelog

* Add `--replace-indexer` flag
* Change `remove_indexer` to remove the indexer, grapgl related entries, and schema tables.
* Remove `forc index revert` and all mentions from the docs.

title: enhancement: support list types in schema macro
body:
_Note: This is being merged into a feature branch._

### Description
Allows for list types to be properly decoded in the schema macro. Note that this does not implement querying for list types, which will come at a later time.

### Testing steps
CI should pass as there should be no outward changes just yet. Proper tests will be added to the feature branch at a later time.

#### Manual Testing
Using the `hello-indexer` example, ensure that the WASM module builds with no errors for the four possible cases:

1. Non-nullable list of non-nullable elements (`Vec<FtColumn>`):
- Add the following to the `Salutation` entity in the schema: `words: [Charfield!]!`
- Add the following line to the `Salutation` struct in the handler: `words: vec!["Hello".to_string()]`
- Ensure that `cargo build` completes successfully.

2. Non-nullable list of nullable elements (`Vec<Option<FtColumn>>`):
- Add the following to the `Salutation` entity in the schema: `words: [Charfield]!`
- Add the following line to the `Salutation` struct in the handler: `words: vec![Some("Hello".to_string())]`
- Ensure that `cargo build` completes successfully.

3. Nullable list of non-nullable elements (`Option<Vec<FtColumn>>`):
- Add the following to the `Salutation` entity in the schema: `words: [Charfield!]`
- Add the following line to the `Salutation` struct in the handler: `words: Some(vec!["Hello".to_string()])`
- Ensure that `cargo build` completes successfully.

4. Nullable list of nullable elements (`Option<Vec<Option<FtColumn>>>`):
- Add the following to the `Salutation` entity in the schema: `words: [Charfield]`
- Add the following line to the `Salutation` struct in the handler: `words: Some(vec![Some("Hello".to_string())])`
- Ensure that `cargo build` completes successfully.

### Changelog

- [Add basic query fragment for list](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/commit/7c77eec25eb6c29d10cefbfcf457e054b78fd72c)
- [Add list type processing to schema macro](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/commit/9fbb08eae3040f2bc7ca5ff21398935a0a857409)

### Description

- PR adds support for a `@norelation` directive
  - Applying this directive to any field on an object renders the entire object as `NoRelation`, which means the object is stored as `Json`
    - I chose `Json` over `Blob` because I think it might be easier to extract the item into an object
      - This will definitely require a second pass later
- PR also moves some code around (moves `serialize` and `deserialize` from fuel-indexer-schema to fuel-indexer-lib)
- 

### Testing steps

- [ ] Test was added so CI should pass
- [ ] Build assets `bash scripts/utils/build_test_wasm_module.bash`
- [ ] Start a local fuel node `cargo run -p fuel-node --bin fuel-node`
- [ ] Start the web API `cargo run -p web-api --bin web-api`
- [ ] Start the service with the test indexer 

```bash
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --manifest packages/fuel-indexer-tests/components/indices/fuel-indexer-test/fuel_indexer_test.yaml --run-migrations
```
- [ ] Trigger some data `curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/block`
- [ ] Open your playground `http://localhost:29987/api/playground/fuel_indexer_test/index1`
- [ ] Make the following query:

```graphql
query {
  usesnotableentity {
    id
    name
    no_table
  }
}
```
- [ ] Should see your type come back as JSON
```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "name": "hello world",
      "no_table": {
        "name": "norelation",
        "size": 1
      }
    }
  ]
}
```
- Note that the item `NoRelationEntity` already comes back as an object straight from the DB, so no further deserialization is needed

### Changelog

- enhancement: add support for a `@norelation` directive that does not create SQL tables for entities

title: Add forc index command to display indexer metadata
body:
### Description

This PR adds a new `forc index` command: `status`. 

1. `fuel-indexer` without authentication enabled returns all indexers:

```
cargo run --release -p forc-index -- status
```
```
┌─ abc
|  └─ another_another_indexer
|     • id: 8
|     • created_at: 2023-05-19 11:19:20.317939 UTC
|     • pubkey: None
|
├─ another_namespace
|  ├─ hello_indexer
|  |  • id: 3
|  |  • created_at: 2023-05-19 10:29:22.521189 UTC
|  |  • pubkey: None
|  └─ another_indexer
|     • id: 6
|     • created_at: 2023-05-19 10:49:19.376889 UTC
|     • pubkey: None
|
├─ foo
|  └─ some_indexer
|     • id: 9
|     • created_at: 2023-05-22 12:27:20.699031 UTC
|     • pubkey: Some("d39783df2aff5c122d53fa765360e65c3eca9ac7106deaae93d061a180acc5fb5da1f91016c912e2f9dd7cd3e899b58f00b3a8a1f217d969995dec6cf0a3852b")
|
├─ fuel_examples
|  └─ hello_indexer
|     • id: 2
|     • created_at: 2023-05-18 13:51:15.705174 UTC
|     • pubkey: None
|
└─ more_fuel_examples
   ├─ hello_indexer
   |  • id: 4
   |  • created_at: 2023-05-19 10:44:29.822645 UTC
   |  • pubkey: None
   ├─ hello_indexer_2
   |  • id: 5
   |  • created_at: 2023-05-19 10:47:31.166200 UTC
   |  • pubkey: None
   └─ another_another_indexer
      • id: 7
      • created_at: 2023-05-19 11:18:45.130328 UTC
      • pubkey: None
```

2. `fuel-indexer` **with authentication** enabled returns only the indexers whose public key matches:

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer -- run --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --run-migrations --auth-enabled --auth-strategy JWT
```

```
cargo run --release -p forc-index -- status
```

```
❌ http://127.0.0.1:29987/api/status returned a non-200 response code: 401
```

Unauthorized!

```
cargo run --release -p forc-index -- status --auth $FUEL_JWT_TOKEN
```
```
─ foo
   └─ some_indexer
      • id: 9
      • created_at: 2023-05-22 12:27:20.699031 UTC
      • pubkey: Some("d39783df2aff5c122d53fa765360e65c3eca9ac7106deaae93d061a180acc5fb5da1f91016c912e2f9dd7cd3e899b58f00b3a8a1f217d969995dec6cf0a3852b")
```

### Testing steps

1. Run `fuel-indexer`
2. Add several indexers, preferably in multiple namespaces
3. Run `cargo run -p forc-index -- status`. It should produce an output similar to the one in the description

### Changelog

* Add `/api/status` endpoint to the API server. Returns a JSON list of all registered indexers.
* Add `status` command to `forc index`, which pretty-prints all namespaces and indexers.

### Description

- Removes the concept of a query root from our GraphQL schema
- Fixes a few bugs in our GraphQL usage
- Updates tests accordingly
- Adds a migration to remove the query root from `graph_registry_graph_root`
- PR also includes a simple hack needed by the GraphQL web functionality (we will remove this eventually)

### Testing steps

- [ ] CI should pass
- [ ] Create an deploy a new indexer project
   - But don't use published crates as a dependency (it will fail)
   - Point your indexer dependencies to this PR branch
- [ ] Examples should work

### Changelog

- fix: remove query root + refactor graphql schema

title: add created_at field to index_registry
body:
### Description

Add the `created_at` column to the `index_registry` table.

### Testing steps

1. Run `fuel-indexer run --run-migrations --manifest PATH`.
2. Connect to `postgres` and run `select * from index_registry;`. `created_at` column should be present and initialized to epoch for any indexer in the table during migration or time of its creation for any indexer added after the migration.

### Changelog

* Add migrations for `created_at` column.
* Update Rust queries, make `register_index` add a timestamp.
* Add `Serializable` instance `#[serde(with = "ts_microseconds")]` (PostgreSQL represents a point in time with microsecond precision).
